qas.question: What threats can hydrogen cause to human saftey?

answers.text: potential detonations and fires when mixed with air to being an asphyxiant in its pure, oxygen-free form

qas.question: What can hydrogen embrittlement lead to?

context: Hydrogen poses a number of hazards to human safety, from <a0_0>potential detonations and fires when mixed with air to being an asphyxiant in its pure, oxygen-free form<a0_0/>. In addition, liquid hydrogen is a cryogen and presents dangers (such as frostbite) associated with very cold liquids. Hydrogen dissolves in many metals, and, in addition to leaking out, may have adverse effects on them, such as hydrogen embrittlement, leading to <a1_0>cracks and explosions<a1_0/>. Hydrogen gas leaking into external air may spontaneously ignite. Moreover, hydrogen fire, while being extremely hot, is almost invisible, and thus can lead to accidental burns.
